body.descriptionTea: ASD is a developmental disorder that affects how a person relates to the world and those around them. People with autism may have difficulties in communication and social interaction, and may exhibit repetitive behaviors and interests.
body.descriptionCharacteristicsTea: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) presents symptoms that can vary in each child. Common signs include difficulty communicating or maintaining eye contact, repetitive behaviors like rocking or flapping, a preference for routine and resistance to change, and challenges in understanding emotions or social interaction.
body.descriptionHelpDiagnostic: This section provides information and support for people who have recently received an autism diagnosis.
body.infoCharacteristicsTea: Learn about the common characteristics and signs of autism for early and accurate identification.
body.infoTreatments: Explore different treatments and therapies that can aid in the development and well-being of people with autism.
body.infoDiagnosis: This section provides information and support for people who have recently received an autism diagnosis.
body.infoEvents: Explore our events and stay updated with all our activities so you don’t miss any.
body.infoAboutUs: Learn more about us and our mission to support people with ASD and their families.
body.descriptionAboutUs: We are excited to share our journey and everything that drives us forward.
body.descriptionCount1: Meet the members who are part of our community.
body.descriptionCount2: Discover our history and how we have grown over the years.
body.descriptionCount3: Meet the members of our board of directors and their commitment to our mission.
body.aboutDescription1: Hello! We are APAZA, an association formed by families united by a common purpose: supporting people with ASD, committed to
body.aboutDescription3: with the goal of improving the quality of life for people with ASD and their families through advice, shared experiences, and a mutual help space.
body.aboutDescription4: Our association was born from the effort and solidarity of families who decided to come together to make a difference and create an environment of support and understanding.
body.aboutDescription5: With a vision focused on building more inclusive communities and an unwavering commitment to
body.aboutDescription7: we continue working together to provide resources, practical advice, and a space where families can feel supported.

body.phrase: Together building a more inclusive future for people with ASD.
body.infoText: This project supports the APAZA organization with the collaboration of TCU-663 and TCU-751 Guápiles. Participating students: - Jeikel Medrano Montesino - Jonnathan García Loria - Elías Mena Fonseca - Diego Ríos Saborío

body.aboutDescription1: From our roots as a small group of
body.aboutDescription2: families united by love and hope,
body.aboutDescription3: we have grown with a single goal: to improve the quality of life for our children with autism.
body.aboutDescription4: Today, thanks to the support of organizations like
body.aboutDescription6: and the strength of our community, we continue building together a future filled with
body.misionDescription3: of people with Autism Spectrum Disorder, with respect and tolerance, working as a team to defend and promote their rights, ensuring a more supportive and fair participation in society.
body.visionDescription3: of people with autism and their families. From the beginning, creating a formative space where the necessary tools are provided for effective inclusion in society.
body.timelineDescription1: a group of parents with children diagnosed with autism met for the first time. This gathering marked the beginning of a transformative journey in the search for improving their loved ones' quality of life. As the group grew, the need to raise awareness about autism became evident, starting with the parents and families themselves and extending to the community. The goal was clear: to integrate people with autism into society with dignity and respect.
body.timelineDescription2: the association held its first activity in commemoration of World Autism Awareness Day, declared by the United Nations General Assembly on December 18, 2007. During this significant commemoration, various cultural events were held to highlight the importance of inclusion.
body.timelineDescription3: On April 17, 2011, the Constitutive Assembly was held, where parents, united by their commitment and passion, took the first steps to formalize their collective effort for the benefit of their children.
body.timelineDescription4: Finally, on October 3, 2011, the Association of People with Autism of the Atlantic Zone, known by its acronym as APAZA, was officially registered as a legally constituted association under Law 218. This milestone marked an important advancement in our mission to promote inclusion and provide support to families affected by autism in the region.
